I love your enthusiasm for space stuff. Watching these videos takes me back to my childhood where I built model rockets, looked through my telescope every night and dreamt of becoming an astronaut. I even went into the air force in hopes of becoming a pilot to then become an astronaut (back then, they were all pilots). I feel like a kid again with SpaceX. Unfortunately, I never got to follow that dream, but I love watching videos of people as giddy as I am when a rocket takes off. Thank you for your videos. I even envy you for getting to do this job. GTO-1800 is what you are looking for, as it's the sub-synchronous Geostationary transfer orbit the sat was put in. GTO-1800 is a lower energy GTO orbit. most sub-synchronous GTOs are in the 1500 range. So yeah, the Sat has to do a bit more work, and will take a bit longer to get to it's operational orbit.

I'm confused, can somebody help please? 57:50 confirmed we're in a geostationary orbit. We're over the coast of Gabon according to the map showing the location of the second stage. So why is the trajectory not parallel to the equator at this point - surely to remain geostationary, the orbit must be perpendicular to the axis of rotation of the planet?? The other thing is, at the beginning, the purpose of the satellite was said to provide satellite services to Asia, so if we are geostationary, why are we over Africa? Thanks to anyone who's smarter than me and can explain!

comment_text: The way they cool oxygen is by first compressing it, then decompressing it quickly through an orifice. As it expands it's cooled off. The cooled off gas is then used to cool the pressurised oxygen tank. So the gaz coming out get colder and colder. Eventually it turns liquid and it is then harvested in insulated containers.

Morning Tim, this was a great launch, I was watching you live from the cape (my 1st live launch) and I managed to introduce you to a couple of other people who were watching the launch, they were watching the SpaceX Livestream and I convinced them to switch streams to you, both said afterwards that they'll continue to watch you in the future and i physically saw both of them hit the subscribe button !! I was watching from the A1A bridge which I've got to say, even though the rocket was 12 miles away I had a totally uninterrupted line of sight over the water, for anyone reading this who has been putting off going to a live launch...STOP and make sure you go,. TV and Livestreams do NOT do a launch Justice !!  I didn't expect it to be as bright as it was lighting up a Huge area to almost daylight or brighter depending on where you were, the sound is unlike anything you've heard, I was 12 miles away and could still physically feel the rumbles from the sounds, this is a launch I won't ever forget !!!

My cryocooler uses Helium as a working fluid.  When it is compressed the atoms gain kinetic energy, in other words it gets warmer, and when it is expanded, the Helium atoms loses kinetic energy, in other words it gets colder, similar to when you spray out the contents of an aerosol can the can gets colder.  This method can be used to move heat from where the gas is expanded to where it is compressed, not that unlike your refrigerator, except that there is no phase change in the Helium.  Also the Warm side of the Helium is chilled with an alcohol/water fluid that is also chilled using more traditional refrigeration compressor to drain off as much heat as possible from the compressed Helium before it is expanded.  In this system the Helium can get the cold side below the temperatures at which nitrogen condenses (-196C or so).  Since this is colder than the temperature at which either Oxygen (-181C or so) or Methane (-161C or so) compress, a similar, if supersized method, is likely used for chilling and liquefying the fuel and oxidizer for larger rockets whose fuel needs cryogenic chilling.
